moves.3... exd4 4. Bc4: Scotch Gambit. Transposes to lots of openings so black has to be careful, but with accurate play white should get a small(or no advantage).
moves.4... Nf6 5. Ng5: Perreux variation. I have been looking at this line a lot more lately. The other options are the Max Lange(which i enjoy) and the main line 5. 0-0 5. Nxe4 6. Re1 6. d5 7. Bxd5 7. Qxd5 8. Nc3 8. Qa5(or h5) and 9. Nxe4 (which i do not).
moves.5... d5: The strongest response *if* black plays carefully the next few moves
moves.6. exd5 Qe7+: ! not 6. Nxd5? 6. 0-0 when white tranposes into a favorable variation of the Loli attack.
moves.7. Kf1: ! the best way to go for an advantage.
moves.9... Qc5 10. Qxc5 Bxc5: Basically white is up a pawn but must consolidate his king position in a queenless middle game.
moves.15... Rfe8: Now we actually have to start thinking.
moves.16. d6: White's extra pawn is very dangerous, but the two black bishops and rook and knight are all ready to jump on the white king.
moves.16... Rac8 17. h3: ?! I think h4 is slightly more accurate in this position
moves.17... h6 18. Nge4: ?! This is a good move.... but the problem is 18.Nce4! is just much better. Often in this line of the perreux variation if white can tactically take control of the e4 square he has a good position.
